F1: Well, that's true. We've been there too, but like many others, we're bouncing back and are looking to expand.

to find out if he needs X-rays
to see if he knows how to brush well
to see if his two cavities have been filled

Material.Text: M1: Good morning, everyone. Iâ€™d like to address some rumors going around about layoffs. A few of you have come to me personally asking about this. It's true that there are going to be some staffing changes but not layoffs. We've been working on something behind the scenes, which I can now confirm. As of next month, we'll be part of Wharton Incorporated. [momentary pause] Now, I know it must be a big surprise to hear that we're merging with one of our biggest rivals, but it's good news. Wharton is in excellent financial shape, and is really looking to grow. Therefore, they won't be letting anyone go, but as we work to streamline our operations, people may be assigned to different departments.

QuestionText.Text: What have some employees talked to the speaker about?

AnswerSentence.Text: their concerns about possible job cuts

QuestionText.Text: What does the speaker say will happen to the company next month?

AnswerSentence.Text: It will be bought by a competitor.
It will move to a different city.

QuestionText.Text: What does the speaker say may happen to some employees?

Material.Text:
Search Engine Optimization: Increase Your Web Traffic

Instructor: Jason Glines
Section A: Thurs. 8:00-9:30 p.m. from May 3-17
Section B: Wed. 7:00-8:30 p.m. from May 18-31
Maximum enrollment: 20 students per section
Location: Building 307, Room 104, Clark Community College
Fees: $100 course fee + $15 registration fee

Whether you have a new business, an established business, or just a personal website or blog, learning Search Engine Optimization (SEO) techniques can make the difference between ten people finding your website and 10,000 people finding it. In this SEO course, you'll learn proven methods for increasing your visibility in online search results and how to make the most popular search engines promote your website. For more information or to register, go to: www.clarkcommunity.org

QuestionText.Text: What is the main purpose of this class?

AnswerSentence.Text: to teach people how to get more visits to their websites
to teach people how to set up a website
to teach people how to use a search engine
to teach people how to find information online

QuestionText.Text: Who is probably the intended audience for this class?
What can people do at the website?

Material.Text: Bionic exoskeletons, or "wearable robots," sound like something out of a science-fiction movie. They are real, however, and are now making their way into people's lives. While one might think that the objective of these exoskeletons is to turn us into superheroes, the truth is they are helping certain people to move and walk again. For many bionic exoskeleton designs, the exoskeleton user straps on the machine to his or her legs, back, and arms, and then is able to move thanks to battery-powered motors that move the legs. The machine is noninvasive and uses external sensors to maintain balance and propel the user into motion. This generation of technology is opening a world of possibilities for patients with particular injuries.

QuestionText.Text: What is the main purpose of this text?

AnswerSentence.Text: to describe a new device used for medical purposes
to discuss how movies have influenced scientific advances
to compare the use of machines in movies and real life
to show robots are being used to help people heal faster

QuestionText.Text: Why does the author mention superheroes?

AnswerSentence.Text: to show that some have unrealistic expectations about exoskeletons
to explain why exoskeletons were first developed
to express admiration for the uses of exoskeletons
to imagine ways exoskeletons may be used in the future

QuestionText.Text: Which of these features makes the device noninvasive?

AnswerSentence.Text: It can be used with patients with impaired mobility.

Material.Text:
The City Arts Foundation in collaboration with the DreamBig Initiative hereby submit for consideration our request for a city improvement grant to construct a multimedia arts center in the developing warehouse district.

The benefits of the project would be numerous. First, engagement with the arts is known to improve community spirit and lead to happier, more connected neighborhoods. Second, it would provide a safe and productive after-school space for teenagers, in addition to tools and workspace for artists ranging from visual and performance artists to writers. Last, it could host free exhibitions and performances for the public.

Included in the submission are the results of a survey conducted locally, indicating that a majority of citizens favor the proposal. In fact, respondents stated that they preferred an arts center to other developments, such as a sports park, due to the lack of art-oriented spaces in our city.

QuestionText.Text: What is the authorâ€™s purpose in writing this text?

AnswerSentence.Text: to persuade leaders to fund a proposal
to explain the benefits of community arts
to announce a new community center
to request information about a city project

QuestionText.Text: What does the author imply about the warehouse district?

AnswerSentence.Text: It is changing for the better.
It is an artistic part of the city.
It is where a park is located.
It is the city councilâ€™s top concern.

QuestionText.Text: Why does the author mention a survey?

AnswerSentence.Text: to provide evidence of support for an idea
to describe a way the city collects information
to request that citizens participate in a study
to suggest a way for citizens to support the arts

Material.Text:
The headlong race to merge has spread to all industrialized countries. In the ten years from 1986 to 1996 mergers went up by 15%, but 1996 was far from the high point. In the first quarter of 1999 alone, more than 2,500 cross-border mergers were signed. The stock market followed in their wake by pushing up the share prices of the companies concerned.
But will all this corporate shopping be good for economies around the globe? Some experts say that mergers are the result of deregulation. Fierce competition has always been a strong incentive to merge. Companies can expect to benefit from economies of scale and boost their market share. Additionally, if there's good synergy between merged corporations, increases in profits can be achieved in all areas.

QuestionText.Text: According to the text, which of these statements best describes the merger growth curve?

AnswerSentence.Text: The merging phenomenon reached its peak in 1999.
Mergers were at their highest point in 1996.
Mergers have increased steadily by 15% a year over the last few decades.
The number of international mergers is expected to decrease with globalization.

QuestionText.Text: According to the text, what is an advantage of merging?

AnswerSentence.Text: attracting more investors with affordable stock

QuestionText.Text: Which word best describes the portrayal of mergers in the text?
